results.comment: Whakapapa. During our last stocktake in Accra we learned from the legendary rugby team ‘All Blacks’ not only how to have top notch performance but how to maintain it. ‘Whakapapa’ encourages us to leave a paradigm-changing legacy in the WCA region. It’s also about planting trees that we will never see. It’s our social footprint. Far from being satisfied with 2019’s results, we have set ambitious targets for 2020 really looking for helping our clients to achieve measurable development outcomes. We will start by systematically fine-tuning outcome measurement in our projects (we are ‘offside’) and boosting up our portfolio early warning systems, while striking the right balance between quantity and quality. Remember that this is everybody’s work (a la ‘clockwork orange’) and not only that of M&E or results specialists. But effective projects are not enough for having systemic results. Rather, we have to spearhead the implementation of new policy delivery tools and instruments, such as government-donors working groups that we are leading now in 8 countries, ASAP +, private sector window, ABC Fund, RBL, RLO, RTA and citizen engagement. The agenda is ambitious and we cannot wait until last minute to push for results. A fresh and smooth start in January ’20 (much better than ’19) indicates that we are on the right track as we already managed to chair one additional policy group in Nigeria, approved a new project in Sao Tome and set ICP in CAR (only one more country to have ICP operational in 100% of WCA!). Let’s change the strategy from being ‘sprinters’ to ‘breakaway specialists’.
results.wcadata:
{"wo":{"0":"
  • Out of the 8 new designs planned for 2020, 6 projects (IVCAD, PRORIR,PADER,P4R, PRIMA, COMPRAN) intend to be gender transformative and 6 projects (IVCAD, PRORIR,PADER, PRIMA, PROGRES, COMPRAN) youth sensitive.
  • COMPRAN was the first gender transformative and youth-sensitive project approved in 2020.
","1":13,"2":null,"3":75,"4":null,"5":1,"6":13,"7":null,"8":75,"9":null,"10":1,"11":"% of approved projects gender transformative","12":"% of approved projects youth-sensitive","13":4,"14":4,"15":"Women and youth","16":"1","17":"Grey"},"cl":{"0":"
  • New designs and FGs over 25 M to be approved in 2020 will account for US$ 182 427 834 of IFAD financing out of which $  45 606 958 should be climate-focused. Total climate finance amount approved so far is US$  485 634. 
  • Out the 8 new design planned for 2020, 6 projects (IVCAD, PRORIR,PADER,P4R, PRIMA, COMPRAN) intend to be nutrition-sensitive
  • COMPRAN was first nutrition-sensitive approved project in 2020.
","1":0.3,"2":null,"3":25,"4":null,"5":1,"6":13,"7":null,"8":75,"9":null,"10":1,"11":"% of POLG climate-focused","12":"% of approved projects nutrition-sensitive","13":4,"14":4,"15":"Climate change and nutrition","16":"2","17":"Grey"},"ap":{"0":"
  • Schussing at full speed! Almost 70% of the delivery approved with Sao Tome COMPRAN being the first project approved in IFAD in 2020.
  • Triple cork type of solutions to be found for Burkina Faso, Niger and Senegal to allocate US$5 M each to the G5 Sahel Regional Lending Operation, despite the countries having already used up their allocations for IFAD11.
  • All new operations should focus on youth and use FIPs whenever possible.
","1":564.1,"2":"JAN 17'","3":827,"4":67,"5":1,"6":20,"7":"JAN 17'","8":30,"9":4,"10":1,"11":"POLG approved, US$ million","12":"Number of operations approved","13":3,"14":3,"15":"Approvals","16":"3","17":"Blue"},"st":{"0":"
  • Cruisin' 2020 COSOPs, as in we can take it easy with the design of the last seven COSOPs of IFAD11:
  • April EB 2020: Guinea and Sierra Leone
  • September EB 2020: Côte d'ivoire, Mali and Gabon
  • December EB 2020: Chad
  • April EB 2021: Togo
","1":11,"2":"JAN 17'","3":18,"4":6,"5":1,"6":null,"7":null,"8":null,"9":null,"10":null,"11":"COSOPs/CSNs approved","12":"% of IFAD news in WCA","13":3,"14":4,"15":"Strategy and visibility","16":"4","17":"Blue"},"co":{"0":"
  • Moguls of domestic co-financing: the path to reach the 0.62 target is not smooth. For the new designs, a consultant will be specifically hired to support the quantification of in-kind contribution.
  • In international co-financing we have been shreddin’ the Gnar, as in riding with exceptional speed and ability. The projections for the end of IFAD11 look very positive, with AfDB as our main partner.
","1":0.43,"2":"JAN 19’","3":0.62,"4":0.42,"5":3,"6":0.49,"7":"JAN 19’","8":0.54,"9":0.38,"10":1,"11":"Domestic ratio\n(3-year rolling)","12":"International ratio\n(3-year rolling)","13":3,"14":3,"15":"Cofinancing","16":"5","17":"Blue"},"ob":{"0":"
  • West and Coastal Africa Hub started the year with lower amounts of ineligibles than in early 19’. On the other side, Central Africa Hub has a relevant increase from 148 k to 288 k. While the main cause of this could be the lift of the suspensions of RC and DRC, there is an urgent need to address this promptly with project teams.
  • Project needing specific focus:
  • PD-PAC, ineligibles for 185 k (55% of all WCA portfolio ineligibles).
","1":335,"2":"JAN 19’","3":300,"4":211,"5":2,"6":2.2,"7":"JAN 19’","8":null,"9":3.5,"10":1,"11":"US$ amount of ineligibles, thousands","12":"US$ amount of outstanding balance, million","13":3,"14":1,"15":"Obligations","16":"6","17":"Grey"},"ri":{"0":"
  • GASIP and PNPER went out of PAR status reducing the number of problem projects to three.
  • Second phase of CASP restructuring is on-going.
  • Cancellation of funds (US$ 21.3) for PROPACOM/W in Côte d'Ivore has been processed and planned for PADER (LOT '20).
","1":14,"2":"OCT 19’","3":10,"4":19,"5":2,"6":33,"7":"JAN 19’","8":20,"9":43,"10":2,"11":"% of problem projects (APP and PPP)","12":"% projects with high financial risk","13":1,"14":1,"15":"Risks","16":"7","17":"Grey"},"ef":{"0":"
  • We are getting started with average cost of design and supervision mission on target. To replicate our unprecedented cost efficiency last year, always keep in mind the \"WCA Decalogue For Resource Management\"
  • Average cost per design of the last four newly approved projects (excluding COMPRAN) is US$ 94 152.
  • Average cost of the last two supervision missions is US$ 54 236.
","1":171,"2":"JAN 19'","3":200,"4":241,"5":1,"6":56,"7":"JAN 19’","8":40,"9":42,"10":1,"11":"US$ cost per design (average), thousand","12":"US$ cost per mission (average), thousand","13":1,"14":3,"15":"Efficiency","16":"8","17":"Grey"},"cm":{"0":"
  • No PCR was expected to be submitted within six month ending January 2020. Likewise, no PCR was expected or publicly disclosed in January 2020.
  • A number of new submissions are expected in the coming months:
  1. SCP (Sierra Leone) expected to be submitted in March
  2. PIRAM (DR. Congo), Nema (Gambia, The), PAPAC (Sao Tome and Principe) and PNAAFA-LGF expansion (Guinea) are expected to be submitted in June
","1":0,"2":"DEC 19'","3":85,"4":100,"5":1,"6":0,"7":"DEC 19'","8":90,"9":50,"10":2,"11":"% PCR submitted within 6 months ","12":"% PCR submitted publicly disclosed","13":1,"14":1,"15":"Completion","16":"9","17":"Grey"},"ag":{"0":"

The holeshot challenge: 12 start-ups were prioritised for a focused approach to speed up the roll-out during 2020. CDs and country teams will populate respective roadmaps and from next SC progress will be tracked here.

","1":9.5,"2":"JAN 19’","3":8,"4":10.2,"5":2,"6":null,"7":null,"8":100,"9":null,"10":null,"11":"Time from CA to EB, months","12":"Start-up progress, %","13":1,"14":4,"15":"Agility","16":"10","17":"Grey"},"re":{"0":"
  • Successful kick-off of AVANTI for Togo.
  • Update and review of all Logframes will start in February for RIDE '20.
  • All projects should conduct outcome surveys at baseline, midterm, and completion using new guidelines. Coordinate with Regional Team for further details and support.
","1":8.4,"2":"JAN 19’","3":15,"4":9.4,"5":3,"6":148.1,"7":"2019","8":136.7,"9":148.2,"10":3,"11":"Outreach, million","12":"Rural extreme poverty, million","13":1,"14":1,"15":"Results","16":"11","17":"Orange"},"di":{"0":"

We started faster than in the same period of 19' and mobilising a larger amount ($ 4.5 M vs. $ 9.4 M). However, we are still far from becoming breakaway specialist as the disbursement ratio target for Q1 is of 6% ($ 86 M).

","1":0.7,"2":"JAN 19'","3":21,"4":0.6,"5":1,"6":15,"7":"JAN 19'","8":12,"9":24,"10":2,"11":"Disbursement ratio","12":"Time from EB to 1st disbursement, months","13":3,"14":1,"15":"Disburse","16":"12","17":"Blue"},"su":{"0":"
  • Seven reports pending for supervision disclosure: PNAAFA - LGF expansion (SM4), PAPFA (SM1), PROPACOM/W (SM6), PIRAM (Partial SM1), TCEP (SM1), PAPAKIN (Partial SM1), and PD-PAC (Partial SM1).
  • We have 4 projects (Neer- Tamba, POSER, CASP, PRODEFI) with no supervision missions reported in the last 12 months.
","1":56,"2":"JAN 19’","3":30,"4":44,"5":3,"6":77,"7":"JAN 19’","8":100,"9":54,"10":3,"11":"Time for disclosure, days (median)","12":"% disclosed or finalised for disclosure","13":3,"14":3,"15":"Supervision","16":"13","17":"Grey"}}

results.comment: A different league. This year has been unprecedented for our division, moving us steps above historical performance and setting a new baseline for delivery, quality and results for 2020 and the years to come. The reforms of IFAD12 will make us play in an even more competitive league, requiring a high performing team, streamlined processes, strengthened partnerships and even more tangible results. 14 staff promoted during 2019 confirms that our team (now with 17 new recruits) can go the extra mile. ICP in almost all of our countries, extensive use of FIPS and reduced time for project design to 10 months show that our processes are leaner and more agile. Cofinancing with the AfDB is bigger than the last 40 years combined, epitomizing that decentralization skyrocketed our partnerships in the region. Results are everywhere: biggest pipeline delivery ever (US$ 590 million, which is bigger than IFAD10 as a whole), biggest disbursement ever (US$ 200 million), virtually zero ineligibles, no countries suspended for the 1st time in two decades, and portfolio-at-risk reduced by half in one year. Transforming our rejuvenated portfolio (full of start-ups) into rapid (yet sustainable) development results is our task for 2020 (we will adapt our Scorecard to track this). Remember that we do not manage projects. Our job is to change lives. Happy 2020!
results.wcadata:
{"wo":{"0":"
  • WCA approved 6 gender transformative projects. These are expected to go beyond gender mainstreaming and seek to transform gendered power dynamics by addressing social norms, practices, attitudes, beliefs and value. Close follow up during implementation will be required for projects to achieve this very ambitious goal (score to be maintained at 6).
  • Leveraging our expertise, 11 projects were approved as youth sensitive. Some projects have made young people their main target. Projects have been able to adopt a specific and differentiated approaches to propose adapted activities for youth employment opportunities.
","1":43,"2":null,"3":45,"4":null,"5":1,"6":79,"7":null,"8":64,"9":null,"10":1,"11":"% of approved projects gender transformative","12":"% of approved projects youth-sensitive","13":4,"14":4,"15":"Women and youth","16":"1","17":"Grey"},"cl":{"0":"
  • All FGs above US$ 25 million and new projects approved used MDB methodology for IFAD climate finance tracking. Climate finance amount approved accounts for 35% (US$ 174 million) of total IFAD amount approved (US$ 490 million) on those 14 operations.
  • Leveraging our expertise, 12 projects were approved nutrition sensitive. Those projects are expected to develop local food systems through the promotion and production of diversified nutritious food and nutrition-sensitive value chains. Close follow up is required at implementation to ensure projects are rated 4 or more.
","1":35,"2":null,"3":26,"4":null,"5":1,"6":86,"7":null,"8":64,"9":null,"10":1,"11":"% of POLG climate-focused","12":"% of approved projects nutrition-sensitive","13":4,"14":4,"15":"Climate change and nutrition","16":"2","17":"Grey"},"ap":{"0":"
  • 67% of IFAD11 total delivery approved in the first year of the cycle with Guinea Bissau approved on the last day of 2019.
  • The delivery of the last 4 months was 7 times higher the one of the first year of IFAD10 (NOV 16'), and higher than that of IFAD10 overall.
","1":558.8,"2":"DEC 16'","3":827,"4":67,"5":1,"6":19,"7":"DEC 16'","8":30,"9":4,"10":1,"11":"POLG approved, US$ million","12":"Number of operations approved","13":3,"14":3,"15":"Approvals","16":"3","17":"Blue"},"st":{"0":"
  • 61% of IFAD11 strategies approved in 2019 doubling the number of strategies of the first year of 2016 (DEC 16')
  • With 9 already approved, the delivery of the COSOPs in 2019 was 1.5 times higher of that of the last two cycles combined.
","1":11,"2":"DEC 16'","3":18,"4":5,"5":1,"6":null,"7":null,"8":null,"9":null,"10":null,"11":"COSOPs/CSNs approved","12":"% of IFAD news in WCA","13":3,"14":4,"15":"Strategy and visibility","16":"4","17":"Blue"},"co":{"0":"
  • Co-financing is moving in the right direction with the International ratio 0.10 points higher than last year. The domestic ratio remains the same if calculated on a 3-year rolling basis. However, if we look exclusively at IFAD11, with the projects approved in 2019 we reached 0.50 and 0.40 of International and Domestic ratio respectively.
","1":0.36,"2":"DEC 18’","3":0.62,"4":0.36,"5":3,"6":0.48,"7":"DEC 18’","8":0.54,"9":0.38,"10":1,"11":"Domestic ratio\n(3-year rolling)","12":"International ratio\n(3-year rolling)","13":2,"14":3,"15":"Cofinancing","16":"5","17":"Blue"},"ob":{"0":"
  • With an increase on ineligibles in the last month the target fall short by a small amount. While Coastal Africa reduced considerable the amount of ineligibles (from $249k in Dec 2018 to $12k in Dec 2019) this had it's trade-off on an increase in Central Africa (from $113k in Dec 2018 to $288k in Dec 2019). West Africa remained the hub with the lowest ineligibles amounts close to zero.
  • In Central Africa, PAPAKIN cleared all its ineligibles ($6.4k), however, new ineligibles were registered for PIRAM ($81k) and PREPAS ($1.7k). PD-PAC continues with the largest ineligible expenditure registered for $185k. To start 2020 with \"zero ineligibles\" a special attention needs to be taken on this hub as its ineligibles represent 94% of all the accumulated ineligibles in WCA.
","1":305,"2":"DEC 18’","3":300,"4":374,"5":1,"6":0.5,"7":"DEC 18’","8":null,"9":2,"10":1,"11":"US$ amount of ineligibles, thousands","12":"US$ amount of outstanding balance, million","13":1,"14":1,"15":"Obligations","16":"6","17":"Grey"},"ri":{"0":"
  • After PAFA-E in Senegal recently left PAR status, WCA's portfolio ends the year with 5 problem projects (out of 27): CASP, PROPACOM/W, PAPSFRA, PNPER and GASIP.
  • Following last supervision missions of PNPER and GASIP, it's very likely that these will leave PAR status, reducing the share of problem projects to 11%.
","1":19,"2":"SEP 19’","3":10,"4":23,"5":2,"6":32,"7":"DEC 18’","8":20,"9":42,"10":2,"11":"% of problem projects (APP and PPP)","12":"% projects with high financial risk","13":1,"14":1,"15":"Risks","16":"7","17":"Grey"},"ef":{"0":"
  • Average cost per design has been on target since the beginning of the year. To remain consistent on our target next year, always keep in mind the \"WCA Decalogue For Resource Management\"
  • The average number of new designs increased considerably this year, and compared to last year, this was done at a lower cost.
  • Average cost per design of the last four newly approved project is US $94 152.
  • Average cost of the two supervision missions in December is US $54 236.
","1":171,"2":"DEC 18'","3":200,"4":241,"5":1,"6":56,"7":"DEC 18’","8":40,"9":43,"10":1,"11":"US$ cost per design (average), thousand","12":"US$ cost per mission (average), thousand","13":1,"14":3,"15":"Efficiency","16":"8","17":"Grey"},"cm":{"0":"
  • Further enhancing this year's unprecedented delivery performance, PADAER (Senegal) PCR was submitted on time amid the holidays season.
  • RMP (Mali) PCR though submitted on time is yet to be publicly disclosed.
  • Importantly, this year marks considerable improvement in PCRs timeliness and disclosure compared to last year.
","1":100,"2":"DEC 18'","3":85,"4":17,"5":1,"6":50,"7":"DEC 18'","8":90,"9":33,"10":2,"11":"% PCR submitted within 6 months ","12":"% PCR submitted publicly disclosed","13":3,"14":3,"15":"Completion","16":"9","17":"Grey"},"ag":{"0":"
  • Project design time was reduced in the last 22 months by more than 4 months, getting closer to the 8 months corporate target.
  • While 1st disb of AVDP (Sierra Leone) was completed this month in 12 months from EB approval -beating the WCA average-, the 1st disb from PADAER-II (Senegal) and RFCIP-II (Sierra Leone) also completed this month took around 20 months which made the agility from EB to 1st disb to get slightly worse. Soon TCEP-II (Liberia) and ProMIFA (Togo) 1st disb will be completed (12 months) allowing the average to go back to the level of Nov (15.7).
","1":9.7,"2":"DEC 18’","3":8,"4":10.2,"5":2,"6":16.1,"7":"DEC 18’","8":12,"9":16.5,"10":3,"11":"Time from CA to EB, months","12":"Time from EB to 1st disbursement, months","13":1,"14":1,"15":"Agility","16":"10","17":"Grey"},"re":{"0":"
  • Successful kick-off of DELIVER in Ghana.
  • Update and review of all Logframes will start in January for RIDE 20'.
  • All projects should conduct outcome surveys at baseline, midterm and completion using new guidelines. Coordinate with Regional Team for further details and support.
","1":7.7,"2":"RIDE 18’","3":15,"4":5.2,"5":3,"6":230.3,"7":"DEC 18'","8":180,"9":228.3,"10":4,"11":"Outreach, million","12":"Extreme poverty, million","13":3,"14":3,"15":"Results","16":"11","17":"Orange"},"di":{"0":"
  • For the first time ever WCA portfolio achieved $200 M on disbursements in a year period! While at end of Dec 2018 the disbursement ratio was slightly better (19.1% vs 18.8%), the amount mobilised to the region had a considerable boost of $31 million from 2018 year-end figures ($169 M vs. $ 200 M).
  • It is expected that due to a relevant amount of WAs that remained in queue in ICP on projects such as GASIP, REP, AGRIFARM or VCDP, the disbursement performance of the portfolio in Jan should exceed the one in the same month of the previous year, however, close monitoring will need to be kept in order to reduce the steepness of the disbursement curve that remained high during the last months of the year.
","1":18.8,"2":"DEC 18'","3":20,"4":19.1,"5":1,"6":7,"7":"DEC 18'","8":6,"9":5.2,"10":1,"11":"Disbursement ratio","12":"Time from 1st to 2nd disbursement, months","13":1,"14":3,"15":"Disburse","16":"12","17":"Blue"},"su":{"0":"
  • By the end of 2019 median time for disclosing a supervision report in the last 12 months in WCA is 80 days, 35 more days than that of April ‘19 and 54 more days than APR (best performing region in this regard). 
  • Reports pending for supervision disclosure are: PAPFA, PROPACOM/W, PARSAT, PIRAM, TCEP, PAPKIN, PEA-J and PNPER.
  • We have 5 projects (POSER, PNAAFA, PRODEFI, PADMAR, Neer-Tamba) with no supervision missions reported in the last 12 months.
","1":80,"2":"DEC 18’","3":30,"4":61,"5":3,"6":65,"7":"DEC 18’","8":100,"9":77,"10":3,"11":"Time for disclosure, days (median)","12":"% disclosed or finalised for disclosure","13":3,"14":1,"15":"Supervision","16":"13","17":"Grey"}}
